ARABIC: وَدَخَلَ جَنَّتَهُۥ وَهُوَ ظَالِمٌ لِّنَفْسِهِۦ قَالَ مَآ أَظُنُّ أَن تَبِيدَ هَٰذِهِۦٓ أَبَدًا

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: He entered his garden and wronged himself by saying, 'I do not think that this will ever end.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: And he walked into his garden, and, (forgetting) his limit, said: "I cannot imagine that this will ever be ruined,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: Then he entered his vine-yard and said, wronging himself: "Surely, I do not believe that all this will ever perish.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: He unjustly entered his garden and said, "I do not think this (property) will ever perish
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: He went into his garden and wronging himself said, “I do not think that this will ever perish.”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: And he went into his garden while having been unjust to himself. He said: "I do not think that this will ever perish."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: And he entered his garden while he was unjust to himself. He said: I do not think that this will ever perish
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: And he entered his garden, wronging himself; he said, 'I do not think that this will ever perish;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: And he went into his garden, while he (thus) wronged himself. He said: I think not that all this will ever perish.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: Having thus harmed his own soul, he entered his garden saying, "I do not think this will ever perish,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: And he entered his garden, while he was a wrong-doer in respect of his own soul; he said: I imagine not that this shall ever perish.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: He entered his garden while he wronged himself. He said, ‘I do not think that this will ever perish,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: He went into his garden in a state (of mind) unjust to his soul: He said, "I deem not that this will ever perish,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: And he went into his garden while in a state (of pride and disbelief) unjust to himself. He said: "I think not that this will ever perish.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: And when, having wronged himself, he entered his garden, he said: 'I do not think that this will ever perish!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: And he entered his garden, wronging himself. He said, “I do not think this will ever perish.”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: And he entered his garden while he was unjust to himself. He said, "I do not think that this will perish - ever.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [18:35] And he entered his garden, [taking] with him his companion, accompanying him all around it, showing him its fruits — God does not say [here] his ‘two gardens’, because what is meant is the beautiful [part of the] garden (rawda); or because [to mention just] one suffices — having wronged himself, through [his] disbelief. He said, ‘I do not think that [all] this will ever perish, become non-existent.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (And he went into his garden, while he (thus) wronged himself) through his disbelief. (He said: I think not that all this will ever perish). 316
